Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an
antidote to this vicious weapon of war. In the process they discovered the gas 
was irrevocably damaging the bone marrow of affected soldiers— halting its 
ability to make blood cells. Despite these awful effects, 
it gave scientists an idea. Cancer cells share a characteristic with 
bone marrow: both replicate rapidly. So could one of the atrocities of war become a champion in the 
fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find 
treatments that did more good than harm, but by the end of World War II, they discovered what became known 
as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered 
through pills and injections and use "cytotoxic agents," which means 
compounds that are toxic to living cells. Essentially, these medicines cause some 
level of harm to all cells in the body— even healthy ones. But they reserve their most powerful 
effects for rapidly-dividing cells, which is precisely the hallmark of cancer. Take, for example, those first 
chemotherapy drugs, which are still used today and 
are called alkylating agents. They’re injected into the bloodstream, which delivers them to 
cells all over the body. Once inside, when the cell exposes 
its DNA in order to copy it, they damage the building blocks of 
DNA’s double helix structure, which can lead to cell death unless 
the damage is repaired. Because cancer cells multiply rapidly, they take in a high concentration 
of alkylating agents, and their DNA is frequently exposed 
and rarely repaired. So they die off more often 
than most other cells, which have time to fix damaged DNA and don’t accumulate the same 
concentrations of alkylating agents. Another form of chemotherapy involves 
compounds called microtubule stabilizers. Cells have small tubes that assemble 
to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers 
get inside a cell, they keep those tiny tubes 
from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing 
its replication, leading to its death. These are just two examples of the six 
classes of chemotherapy drugs we use to treat cancer today. But despite its huge benefits, 
chemotherapy has one big disadvantage: it affects other healthy cells in the body
that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth, 
the gastrointestinal lining, the reproductive system, and bone marrow 
are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid 
production of these normal cells means that they’re reaching for 
resources more frequently— and are therefore more exposed to 
the effects of chemo drugs. That leads to several common side 
effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,
nausea, and vomiting. Doctors commonly prescribe options 
to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps 
can help lower the temperature around the head and 
constrict blood vessels, limiting the amount of chemotherapy 
drugs that reach hair follicles. And once a course of chemo 
treatment is over, the healthy tissues that’ve been badly 
affected by the drug will recover and begin to renew as usual. In 2018 alone, over 17 million people 
world-wide received a cancer diagnosis. But chemotherapy and other treatments 
have changed the outlook for so many. Just take the fact that up to 95% of 
individuals with testicular cancer survive it, thanks to advances 
in treatment. Even in people with acute myeloid 
leukemia— an aggressive blood cancer— chemotherapy puts an estimated 
60% of patients under 60 into remission following their 
first phase of treatment. Researchers are still developing 
more precise interventions that only target the intended 
cancer cells. That’ll help improve survival rates 
while leaving healthy tissues with reduced harm, making one of the best tools we have 
in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cells have small tubes that assemble and disassemble to help with cell division and DNA replication. Microtubule Stabilizers work by ___________.
Options: A. Preventing those tubes from disassembling., B. Preventing those tubes from assembling., C. Disallowing growth of those tubes., D. Damaging the building blocks of DNA’s double helix structure.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was one of the horrors of trench warfare during World War I? Options: A. The introduction of antibiotics, B. The use of mustard gas, C. The invention of chemotherapy, D. The discovery of the bone marrow's ability to make blood cells Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is a characteristic that both bone marrow and cancer cells share? Options: A. The ability to repair damaged DNA, B. The ability to replicate rapidly, C. The ability to produce antibodies, D. The ability to fight off infections Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the result of injecting compounds derived from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients in the 1930s? Options: A. The development of new chemotherapy drugs, B. The discovery of a cure for cancer, C. The improvement of radiation therapy, D. The increase in the use of surgery Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the primary mechanism of action of alkylating agents in chemotherapy? Options: A. They damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. They stimulate the production of antibodies, C. They increase the production of white blood cells, D. They reduce the risk of infection Correct Option: A
Question 5: Which of the following is a common side effect of chemotherapy? Options: A. Hair loss, B. Fatigue, C. Infertility, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of microtubule stabilizers in chemotherapy? Options: A. To damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. To stimulate the production of antibodies, C. To prevent the disassembly of microtubules, D. To increase the production of white blood cells Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the estimated survival rate for individuals with testicular cancer? Options: A. 50%, B. 70%, C. 90%, D. Up to 95% Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the primary goal of researchers in developing more precise interventions in chemotherapy? Options: A. To increase the side effects of chemotherapy, B. To reduce the harm to healthy tissues, C. To increase the cost of chemotherapy, D. To decrease the effectiveness of chemotherapy Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, how many people worldwide received a cancer diagnosis in 2018? Options: A. 10 million, B. 15 million, C. 17 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the outlook for cancer treatment according to the transcript? Options: A. It is becoming less effective, B. It is becoming more expensive, C. It is becoming more precise and effective, D. It is becoming less common Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 6: What is the purpose of microtubule stabilizers in chemotherapy? 

Options: A. To damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. To stimulate the production of antibodies, C. To prevent the disassembly of microtubules, D. To increase the production of white blood cells 

Correct Option: C

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the mechanism of action of microtubule stabilizers, and both have the correct answer that microtubule stabilizers work by preventing the disassembly of microtubules.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 6

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an

fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find

as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered

to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers 
get inside a cell, they keep those tiny tubes 
from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing

classes of chemotherapy drugs we use to treat cancer today. But despite its huge benefits,

that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth,

are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid

effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,

to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps

in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The first chemotherapy drugs, which are still used today, are called ____________.
Options: A. Microtubule Stabilizers, B. Anti-tumor antibiotics, C. Topoisomerase inhibitiors, D. Alkylating Agents
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was one of the horrors of trench warfare during World War I? Options: A. The introduction of antibiotics, B. The use of mustard gas, C. The invention of chemotherapy, D. The discovery of the bone marrow's ability to make blood cells Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is a characteristic that both bone marrow and cancer cells share? Options: A. The ability to repair damaged DNA, B. The ability to replicate rapidly, C. The ability to produce antibodies, D. The ability to fight off infections Correct Option: B
Question 3: What was the result of injecting compounds derived from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients in the 1930s? Options: A. The development of new chemotherapy drugs, B. The discovery of a cure for cancer, C. The improvement of radiation therapy, D. The increase in the use of surgery Correct Option: A
Question 4: What is the primary mechanism of action of alkylating agents in chemotherapy? Options: A. They damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. They stimulate the production of antibodies, C. They increase the production of white blood cells, D. They reduce the risk of infection Correct Option: A
Question 5: Which of the following is a common side effect of chemotherapy? Options: A. Hair loss, B. Fatigue, C. Infertility, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of microtubule stabilizers in chemotherapy? Options: A. To damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. To stimulate the production of antibodies, C. To prevent the disassembly of microtubules, D. To increase the production of white blood cells Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the estimated survival rate for individuals with testicular cancer? Options: A. 50%, B. 70%, C. 90%, D. Up to 95% Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the primary goal of researchers in developing more precise interventions in chemotherapy? Options: A. To increase the side effects of chemotherapy, B. To reduce the harm to healthy tissues, C. To increase the cost of chemotherapy, D. To decrease the effectiveness of chemotherapy Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, how many people worldwide received a cancer diagnosis in 2018? Options: A. 10 million, B. 15 million, C. 17 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the outlook for cancer treatment according to the transcript? Options: A. It is becoming less effective, B. It is becoming more expensive, C. It is becoming more precise and effective, D. It is becoming less common Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 7, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an
antidote to this vicious weapon of war. In the process they discovered the gas 
was irrevocably damaging the bone marrow of affected soldiers— halting its 
ability to make blood cells. Despite these awful effects, 
it gave scientists an idea. Cancer cells share a characteristic with 
bone marrow: both replicate rapidly. So could one of the atrocities of war become a champion in the 
fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find 
treatments that did more good than harm, but by the end of World War II, they discovered what became known 
as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered 
through pills and injections and use "cytotoxic agents," which means 
compounds that are toxic to living cells. Essentially, these medicines cause some 
level of harm to all cells in the body— even healthy ones. But they reserve their most powerful 
effects for rapidly-dividing cells, which is precisely the hallmark of cancer. Take, for example, those first 
chemotherapy drugs, which are still used today and 
are called alkylating agents. They’re injected into the bloodstream, which delivers them to 
cells all over the body. Once inside, when the cell exposes 
its DNA in order to copy it, they damage the building blocks of 
DNA’s double helix structure, which can lead to cell death unless 
the damage is repaired. Because cancer cells multiply rapidly, they take in a high concentration 
of alkylating agents, and their DNA is frequently exposed 
and rarely repaired. So they die off more often 
than most other cells, which have time to fix damaged DNA and don’t accumulate the same 
concentrations of alkylating agents. Another form of chemotherapy involves 
compounds called microtubule stabilizers. Cells have small tubes that assemble 
to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers 
get inside a cell, they keep those tiny tubes 
from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing 
its replication, leading to its death. These are just two examples of the six 
classes of chemotherapy drugs we use to treat cancer today. But despite its huge benefits, 
chemotherapy has one big disadvantage: it affects other healthy cells in the body
that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth, 
the gastrointestinal lining, the reproductive system, and bone marrow 
are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid 
production of these normal cells means that they’re reaching for 
resources more frequently— and are therefore more exposed to 
the effects of chemo drugs. That leads to several common side 
effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,
nausea, and vomiting. Doctors commonly prescribe options 
to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps 
can help lower the temperature around the head and 
constrict blood vessels, limiting the amount of chemotherapy 
drugs that reach hair follicles. And once a course of chemo 
treatment is over, the healthy tissues that’ve been badly 
affected by the drug will recover and begin to renew as usual. In 2018 alone, over 17 million people 
world-wide received a cancer diagnosis. But chemotherapy and other treatments 
have changed the outlook for so many. Just take the fact that up to 95% of 
individuals with testicular cancer survive it, thanks to advances 
in treatment. Even in people with acute myeloid 
leukemia— an aggressive blood cancer— chemotherapy puts an estimated 
60% of patients under 60 into remission following their 
first phase of treatment. Researchers are still developing 
more precise interventions that only target the intended 
cancer cells. That’ll help improve survival rates 
while leaving healthy tissues with reduced harm, making one of the best tools we have 
in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Despite its huge benefits in attacking cancer cells, chemotherapy has one big disadvantage:
Options: A. It affects other healthy cells in the body., B. It always requires a combination of medications to be effective., C. It is a new, unproven treatment., D. It only works on slow growing cells.
Correct Option: A

They increase the production of white blood cells, D. They reduce the risk of infection Correct Option: A
Question 5: Which of the following is a common side effect of chemotherapy? Options: A. Hair loss, B. Fatigue, C. Infertility, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the purpose of microtubule stabilizers in chemotherapy? Options: A. To damage the DNA of rapidly-dividing cells, B. To stimulate the production of antibodies, C. To prevent the disassembly of microtubules, D. To increase the production of white blood cells Correct Option: C
Question 7: According to the transcript, what is the estimated survival rate for individuals with testicular cancer? Options: A. 50%, B. 70%, C. 90%, D. Up to 95% Correct Option: D
Question 8: What is the primary goal of researchers in developing more precise interventions in chemotherapy? Options: A. To increase the side effects of chemotherapy, B. To reduce the harm to healthy tissues, C. To increase the cost of chemotherapy, D. To decrease the effectiveness of chemotherapy Correct Option: B
Question 9: According to the transcript, how many people worldwide received a cancer diagnosis in 2018? Options: A. 10 million, B. 15 million, C. 17 million, D. 20 million Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the outlook for cancer treatment according to the transcript? Options: A. It is becoming less effective, B. It is becoming more expensive, C. It is becoming more precise and effective, D. It is becoming less common Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud

than most other cells, which have time to fix damaged DNA and don’t accumulate the same

to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers

from disassembling. That prevents the cell from completing

that naturally have to renew rapidly. Hair follicles, the cells of the mouth, 
the gastrointestinal lining, the reproductive system, and bone marrow 
are hit nearly as hard as cancer. Similar to cancer cells, the rapid 
production of these normal cells means that they’re reaching for 
resources more frequently— and are therefore more exposed to 
the effects of chemo drugs. That leads to several common side 
effects of chemotherapy, including hair loss, fatigue, infertility,
nausea, and vomiting. Doctors commonly prescribe options 
to help manage these side-effects, such as strong anti-nausea medications. For hair loss, devices called cold caps 
can help lower the temperature around the head and 
constrict blood vessels, limiting the amount of chemotherapy 
drugs that reach hair follicles. And once a course of chemo 
treatment is over, the healthy tissues that’ve been badly 
affected by the drug will recover and begin to renew as usual. In 2018 alone, over 17 million people 
world-wide received a cancer diagnosis. But chemotherapy and other treatments 
have changed the outlook for so many. Just take the fact that up to 95% of 
individuals with testicular cancer survive it, thanks to advances 
in treatment. Even in people with acute myeloid 
leukemia— an aggressive blood cancer— chemotherapy puts an estimated 
60% of patients under 60 into remission following their 
first phase of treatment. Researchers are still developing 
more precise interventions that only target the intended 
cancer cells. That’ll help improve survival rates 
while leaving healthy tissues with reduced harm, making one of the best tools we have 
in the fight against cancer even better.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cells have small tubes that assemble and disassemble to help with cell division and DNA replication. Microtubule Stabilizers work by ___________.
Options: A. Preventing those tubes from disassembling., B. Preventing those tubes from assembling., C. Disallowing growth of those tubes., D. Damaging the building blocks of DNA’s double helix structure.
Correct Option: A

**Transcript**:
During World War I, one of the 
horrors of trench warfare was a poisonous yellow cloud 
called mustard gas. For those unlucky enough to be exposed, it made the air impossible to breathe, 
burned their eyes, and caused huge blisters on exposed skin. Scientists tried desperately to develop an
antidote to this vicious weapon of war. In the process they discovered the gas 
was irrevocably damaging the bone marrow of affected soldiers— halting its 
ability to make blood cells. Despite these awful effects, 
it gave scientists an idea. Cancer cells share a characteristic with 
bone marrow: both replicate rapidly. So could one of the atrocities of war become a champion in the 
fight against cancer? Researchers in the 1930s 
investigated this idea by injecting compounds derived 
from mustard gas into the veins of cancer patients. It took time and trial and error to find 
treatments that did more good than harm, but by the end of World War II, they discovered what became known 
as the first chemotherapy drugs. Today, there are more than 100. Chemotherapy drugs are delivered 
through pills and injections and use "cytotoxic agents," which means 
compounds that are toxic to living cells. Essentially, these medicines cause some

to help with cell division and DNA replication, then break back down. When microtubule stabilizers

in the fight against cancer even better.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits 
are widely acknowledged, and some nations 
have legalized medical use or are moving in that direction. But a growing recognition 
for marijuana’s medical value doesn’t answer the question: is recreational marijuana use 
bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors 
all over the brain and body. Molecules native to the body, 
called endocannabinoids, also act on these receptors. We don’t totally understand 
the cannabinoid system, but it has one feature 
that provides a big clue to its function. Most neurotransmitters 
travel from one neuron to the next through a synapse to propagate a message. But endocannabinoids 
travel in the opposite direction. When a message passes 
from the one neuron to the next, the receiving neuron 
releases endocannabinoids. Those endocannabinoids 
travel backward to influence the sending neuron— essentially giving it feedback 
from the receiving neuron. This leads scientists 
to believe that the endocannabinoid system serves primarily 
to modulate other kinds of signals— amplifying some and diminishing others. Feedback from endocannabinoids 
slows down rates of neural signaling. That doesn’t necessarily mean it slows down behavior 
or perception, though. For example, 
slowing down a signal that inhibits smell could actually make smells more intense. Marijuana contains 
two main active compounds, tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, 
and cannabidiol, or CBD. THC is thought to be primarily responsible
for marijuana’s psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, while CBD is responsible 
for the non-psychoactive effects. Like endocannabinoids, THC slows down signaling 
by binding to cannabinoid receptors. But it binds to receptors 
all over this sprawling, diffuse system at once, whereas endocannabinoids 
are released in a specific place in response to a specific stimulus. This widespread activity 
coupled with the fact that the cannabinoid system
indirectly affects many other systems, means that each person’s 
particular brain chemistry, genetics, and previous life experience largely determine 
how they experience the drug. That’s true much more so with marijuana 
than with other drugs that produce their effects 
through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know 
how exactly how marijuana produces specific harmful effects, there are clear risk factors 
that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old 
than a 22 year old, for instance. Marijuana can also cause hallucinations 
or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking 
a persistent psychotic disorder. A family history of psychotic disorders, 
like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only, 
risk factor for this effect. Marijuana-induced psychosis 
is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following are active compounds in marijuana?
Options: A. THC, B. CBD, C. THC and CBD, D. None of the above
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial classification of marijuana in the United States in 1970? Options: A. Schedule 2, B. Schedule 1, C. Schedule 3, D. Schedule 4 Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of the endocannabinoid system? Options: A. To amplify neural signaling, B. To modulate other kinds of signals, C. To propagate messages between neurons, D. To release neurotransmitters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main active compound responsible for marijuana's psychoactive effects? Options: A. Cannabidiol (CBD), B. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the cannabinoid system indirectly affect other systems in the body? Options: A. By binding to specific receptors, B. By releasing endocannabinoids, C. By slowing down neural signaling, D. By amplifying neural signaling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the relationship between age and the concentration of cannabinoid receptors in the white matter? Options: A. Older individuals have more concentrated receptors, B. Younger individuals have more concentrated receptors, C. There is no relationship between age and receptor concentration, D. The relationship is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary risk factor for marijuana-induced psychosis? Options: A. Family history of psychotic disorders, B. Age, C. Frequent marijuana use, D. Both A and B Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the effect of marijuana on the brain's ability to grow new connections? Options: A. It enhances the growth of new connections, B. It has no effect on the growth of new connections, C. It disrupts the development of white matter tracts, D. It slows down the growth of new connections Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the difference between the effects of THC and CBD on the brain? Options: A. THC amplifies neural signaling, while CBD slows it down, B. THC slows down neural signaling, while CBD amplifies it, C. THC and CBD have the same effects on the brain, D. The difference is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the likelihood of experiencing negative effects from marijuana use? Options: A. It is impossible to experience negative effects, B. It is unlikely to experience negative effects, C. It depends on individual risk factors, D. It is likely to experience negative effects Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary factor that determines how individuals experience the effects of marijuana? Options: A. Age, B. Brain chemistry, C. Genetics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3: What is the main active compound responsible for marijuana's psychoactive effects? Options: A. Cannabidiol (CBD), B. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: B.

However, this question does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as it only asks about the main active compound responsible for psychoactive effects, whereas the ground truth MCQ asks about the active compounds in marijuana in general.

A more similar question would be one that asks about the active compounds in marijuana, including both THC and CBD. Unfortunately, none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

But if I had to choose, I would say that Question 3 is the closest match, although it's not perfect.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 3

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits 
are widely acknowledged, and some nations 
have legalized medical use or are moving in that direction. But a growing recognition 
for marijuana’s medical value doesn’t answer the question: is recreational marijuana use 
bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors 
all over the brain and body. Molecules native to the body, 
called endocannabinoids, also act on these receptors. We don’t totally understand 
the cannabinoid system, but it has one feature 
that provides a big clue to its function. Most neurotransmitters 
travel from one neuron to the next through a synapse to propagate a message. But endocannabinoids 
travel in the opposite direction. When a message passes 
from the one neuron to the next, the receiving neuron 
releases endocannabinoids. Those endocannabinoids 
travel backward to influence the sending neuron— essentially giving it feedback 
from the receiving neuron. This leads scientists 
to believe that the endocannabinoid system serves primarily 
to modulate other kinds of signals— amplifying some and diminishing others. Feedback from endocannabinoids 
slows down rates of neural signaling. That doesn’t necessarily mean it slows down behavior 
or perception, though. For example, 
slowing down a signal that inhibits smell could actually make smells more intense. Marijuana contains 
two main active compounds, tetrahydrocannabinol or THC, 
and cannabidiol, or CBD. THC is thought to be primarily responsible
for marijuana’s psychoactive effects on behavior, cognition, and perception, while CBD is responsible 
for the non-psychoactive effects. Like endocannabinoids, THC slows down signaling 
by binding to cannabinoid receptors. But it binds to receptors 
all over this sprawling, diffuse system at once, whereas endocannabinoids 
are released in a specific place in response to a specific stimulus. This widespread activity 
coupled with the fact that the cannabinoid system
indirectly affects many other systems, means that each person’s 
particular brain chemistry, genetics, and previous life experience largely determine 
how they experience the drug. That’s true much more so with marijuana 
than with other drugs that produce their effects 
through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know 
how exactly how marijuana produces specific harmful effects, there are clear risk factors 
that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old 
than a 22 year old, for instance. Marijuana can also cause hallucinations 
or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking 
a persistent psychotic disorder. A family history of psychotic disorders, 
like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only, 
risk factor for this effect. Marijuana-induced psychosis 
is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Cannabinoid receptors are more concentrated in the while matter in people younger than:
Options: A. 18, B. 25, C. 14, D. 40
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial classification of marijuana in the United States in 1970? Options: A. Schedule 2, B. Schedule 1, C. Schedule 3, D. Schedule 4 Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of the endocannabinoid system? Options: A. To amplify neural signaling, B. To modulate other kinds of signals, C. To propagate messages between neurons, D. To release neurotransmitters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main active compound responsible for marijuana's psychoactive effects? Options: A. Cannabidiol (CBD), B. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the cannabinoid system indirectly affect other systems in the body? Options: A. By binding to specific receptors, B. By releasing endocannabinoids, C. By slowing down neural signaling, D. By amplifying neural signaling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the relationship between age and the concentration of cannabinoid receptors in the white matter? Options: A. Older individuals have more concentrated receptors, B. Younger individuals have more concentrated receptors, C. There is no relationship between age and receptor concentration, D. The relationship is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary risk factor for marijuana-induced psychosis? Options: A. Family history of psychotic disorders, B. Age, C. Frequent marijuana use, D. Both A and B Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the effect of marijuana on the brain's ability to grow new connections? Options: A. It enhances the growth of new connections, B. It has no effect on the growth of new connections, C. It disrupts the development of white matter tracts, D. It slows down the growth of new connections Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the difference between the effects of THC and CBD on the brain? Options: A. THC amplifies neural signaling, while CBD slows it down, B. THC slows down neural signaling, while CBD amplifies it, C. THC and CBD have the same effects on the brain, D. The difference is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the likelihood of experiencing negative effects from marijuana use? Options: A. It is impossible to experience negative effects, B. It is unlikely to experience negative effects, C. It depends on individual risk factors, D. It is likely to experience negative effects Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary factor that determines how individuals experience the effects of marijuana? Options: A. Age, B. Brain chemistry, C. Genetics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5: What is the relationship between age and the concentration of cannabinoid receptors in the white matter?

This question has a similar intent to the ground truth MCQ, which asks about the age at which cannabinoid receptors are more concentrated in the white matter. The options for Question 5 also align with the ground truth MCQ, with option B stating that younger individuals have more concentrated receptors, which matches the correct option B (25) in the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

In 1970, marijuana was classified 
as a schedule 1 drug in the United States: the strictest designation possible, meaning it was completely illegal 
and had no recognized medical uses. For decades, this view persisted and set back research 
on the drug's mechanisms and effects. Today, marijuana’s therapeutic benefits

bad for your brain? Marijuana acts 
on the body’s cannabinoid system, which has receptors

through one or a few specific pathways. So the harmful effects, if any, 
vary considerably from person to person. And while we don’t know

that can increase peoples’ likelihood of experiencing them. The clearest risk factor is age. In people younger than 25, cannabinoid receptors 
are more concentrated in the white matter than in people over 25. The white matter 
is involved in communication, learning, memory, and emotions. Frequent marijuana use can disrupt the development 
of white matter tracts, and also affect the brain’s ability 
to grow new connections. This may damage long-term learning ability
and problem solving. For now, it’s unclear 
how severe this damage can be or whether it’s reversible. And even among young people, the risk is higher the younger someone is— much higher for a 15 year old

or paranoid delusions. Known as marijuana-induced psychosis, these symptoms usually subside 
when a person stops using marijuana. But in rare cases, 
psychosis doesn’t subside, instead unmasking

like schizophrenia, is the clearest, though not the only,

is also more common among young adults, though it’s worth noting 
that psychotic disorders usually surface in this age range anyway. What’s unclear in these cases 
is whether the psychotic disorder would have appeared 
without marijuana use— whether marijuana use triggers it early, is a catalyst for a tipping point 
that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

that wouldn’t have been crossed otherwise, or whether the reaction 
to marijuana is merely an indication of an underlying disorder. In all likelihood, marijuana’s role 
varies from person to person. At any age, as with many other drugs, the brain and body become less sensitive 
to marijuana after repeated uses, meaning it takes more 
to achieve the same effects. Fortunately, unlike many other drugs, there’s no risk of fatal overdose 
from marijuana, and even heavy use 
doesn’t lead to debilitating or life-threatening 
withdrawal symptoms if use stops. There are more subtle forms 
of marijuana withdrawal, though, including sleep disturbances, 
irritability, and depressed mood, which pass 
within a few weeks of stopping use. So is marijuana bad for your brain? It depends who you are. But while some risk factors 
are easy to identify, others aren’t well understood— which means there’s still some possibility
of experiencing negative effects, even if you don’t have 
any of the known risk factors.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Scientists believe that the endocannabinoid system primarily serves to:
Options: A. Modulate neural signaling, B. Regulate the pace of digestion, C. Reduces metabolism, D. Paces the oxygenation of cells
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the initial classification of marijuana in the United States in 1970? Options: A. Schedule 2, B. Schedule 1, C. Schedule 3, D. Schedule 4 Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary function of the endocannabinoid system? Options: A. To amplify neural signaling, B. To modulate other kinds of signals, C. To propagate messages between neurons, D. To release neurotransmitters Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the main active compound responsible for marijuana's psychoactive effects? Options: A. Cannabidiol (CBD), B. Tetrahydrocannabinol (THC), C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does the cannabinoid system indirectly affect other systems in the body? Options: A. By binding to specific receptors, B. By releasing endocannabinoids, C. By slowing down neural signaling, D. By amplifying neural signaling Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the relationship between age and the concentration of cannabinoid receptors in the white matter? Options: A. Older individuals have more concentrated receptors, B. Younger individuals have more concentrated receptors, C. There is no relationship between age and receptor concentration, D. The relationship is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the primary risk factor for marijuana-induced psychosis? Options: A. Family history of psychotic disorders, B. Age, C. Frequent marijuana use, D. Both A and B Correct Option: A
Question 7: What is the effect of marijuana on the brain's ability to grow new connections? Options: A. It enhances the growth of new connections, B. It has no effect on the growth of new connections, C. It disrupts the development of white matter tracts, D. It slows down the growth of new connections Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the difference between the effects of THC and CBD on the brain? Options: A. THC amplifies neural signaling, while CBD slows it down, B. THC slows down neural signaling, while CBD amplifies it, C. THC and CBD have the same effects on the brain, D. The difference is unclear Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the likelihood of experiencing negative effects from marijuana use? Options: A. It is impossible to experience negative effects, B. It is unlikely to experience negative effects, C. It depends on individual risk factors, D. It is likely to experience negative effects Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is the primary factor that determines how individuals experience the effects of marijuana? Options: A. Age, B. Brain chemistry, C. Genetics, D. All of the above Correct Option: D

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Meet Lucy. She was a math major in college, and aced all her courses in probability 
and statistics. Which do you think is more likely: that 
Lucy is a portrait artist, or that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker? In studies of similar questions, up to 80 
percent of participants chose the equivalent 
of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker. After all, nothing we know about Lucy 
suggests an affinity for art, but statistics and probability 
are useful in poker. And yet, this is the wrong answer. Look at the options again. How do we know the first statement 
is more likely to be true? Because it’s a less specific version 
of the second statement. Saying that Lucy is a portrait artist 
doesn’t make any claims about what else she might or might not do. But even though it’s far easier to imagine
her playing poker than making art based on the background information, the second statement is only true if she 
does both of these things. However counterintuitive it seems 
to imagine Lucy as an artist, the second scenario adds another condition
on top of that, making it less likely. For any possible set of events, the 
likelihood of A occurring will always be greater than the likelihood
of A and B both occurring. If we took a random sample of a million 
people who majored in math, the subset who are portrait artists might 
be relatively small. But it will necessarily be bigger than the subset who are portrait artists 
and play poker. Anyone who belongs to the second group 
will also belong to the first– but not vice versa. The more conditions there are, 
the less likely an event becomes. So why do statements with more conditions
sometimes seem more believable? This is a phenomenon known as 
the conjunction fallacy. When we’re asked to make quick decisions, 
we tend to look for shortcuts. In this case, we look for what seems 
plausible rather than what is statistically 
most probable. On its own, Lucy being an artist doesn’t 
match the expectations formed by the preceding information. The additional detail about 
her playing poker gives us a narrative that resonates 
with our intuitions— it makes it seem more plausible. And we choose the option that seems more
representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability. This effect has been observed 
across multiple studies, including ones with participants 
who understood statistics well– from students betting on 
sequences of dice rolls, to foreign policy experts predicting 
the likelihood of a diplomatic crisis. The conjunction fallacy isn’t just a 
problem in hypothetical situations. Conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction
fallacy to seem credible– the more resonant details are added 
to an outlandish story, the more plausible it begins to seem. But ultimately, the likelihood 
a story is true can never be greater than the probability 
that its least likely component is true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of these sequences of coin flips would you be most likely to bet on?
Options: A. THTHHH, B. THTHHHT, C. HTHHH
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the phenomenon discussed in the transcript where adding more conditions to a statement makes it less likely to be true? Options: A. The conjunction fallacy, B. The probability fallacy, C. The narrative bias, D. The confirmation bias Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what percentage of participants in similar studies chose the equivalent of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker? Options: A. 50%, B. 60%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main reason why the first statement (Lucy is a portrait artist) is more likely to be true than the second statement (Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker)? Options: A. Because it's a more specific version of the second statement, B. Because it's a less specific version of the second statement, C. Because it's a more general statement, D. Because it's a more abstract statement Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what happens when we add more conditions to a statement? Options: A. The likelihood of the statement becomes greater, B. The likelihood of the statement remains the same, C. The likelihood of the statement becomes less, D. The likelihood of the statement becomes more uncertain Correct Option: C
Question 5: In what context is the conjunction fallacy most likely to occur? Options: A. When making quick decisions, B. When analyzing complex data, C. When evaluating evidence, D. When solving mathematical problems Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, why do conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Because they want to seem credible, B. Because they want to seem plausible, C. Because they want to seem believable, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between the likelihood of a statement and the likelihood of its least likely component? Options: A. The likelihood of the statement is always greater than the likelihood of its least likely component, B. The likelihood of the statement is always less than the likelihood of its least likely component, C. The likelihood of the statement is equal to the likelihood of its least likely component, D. The likelihood of the statement can be greater than, less than, or equal to the likelihood of its least likely component Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, why do people tend to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Because they are unaware of the concept, B. Because they are not familiar with statistics, C. Because they look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable, D. Because they are not able to think critically Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between the conjunction fallacy and the narrative bias? Options: A. The conjunction fallacy is a type of narrative bias, B. The narrative bias is a type of conjunction fallacy, C. The conjunction fallacy and narrative bias are unrelated, D. The conjunction fallacy is a result of the narrative bias Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main takeaway from understanding the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. That we should always choose the option that seems most plausible, B. That we should always choose the option that is statistically most probable, C. That we should be aware of the conjunction fallacy and avoid falling victim to it, D. That we should always trust our intuition Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question content, options, and overall intent. However, I can identify a generated MCQ that shares a similar concept and intent.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the likelihood of a sequence of coin flips, which is related to the concept of probability and the conjunction fallacy discussed in the transcript. Among the generated MCQs, Question 4 is the most relevant, as it asks about the effect of adding more conditions to a statement on its likelihood.

Although Question 4 does not specifically ask about coin flips, it addresses the underlying concept of probability and the conjunction fallacy, which is the main idea behind the ground truth MCQ. Therefore, I would identify Question 4 as the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 4

Question 8: According to the transcript, why do people tend to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Because they are unaware of the concept, B. Because they are not familiar with statistics, C. Because they look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable, D. Because they are not able to think critically Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between the conjunction fallacy and the narrative bias? Options: A. The conjunction fallacy is a type of narrative bias, B. The narrative bias is a type of conjunction fallacy, C. The conjunction fallacy and narrative bias are unrelated, D. The conjunction fallacy is a result of the narrative bias Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main takeaway from understanding the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. That we should always choose the option that seems most plausible, B. That we should always choose the option that is statistically most probable, C. That we should be aware of the conjunction fallacy and avoid falling victim to it, D. That we should always trust our intuition Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

Here's why:

- Question intent: Both the ground truth MCQ and Question 8 aim to understand why people fall victim to the conjunction fallacy.
- Options: Although the options are not identical, they both relate to the reasons behind the conjunction fallacy. The correct option in Question 8 (C. Because they look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable) is similar to the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (A. Making snap judgments based on believability rather than calculation).
- Content: Both questions deal with the concept of the conjunction fallacy and the factors that contribute to it.

While there isn't a perfect match, Question 8 is the most similar generated MCQ to the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Meet Lucy. She was a math major in college, and aced all her courses in probability 
and statistics. Which do you think is more likely: that 
Lucy is a portrait artist, or that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker? In studies of similar questions, up to 80 
percent of participants chose the equivalent 
of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist 
who also plays poker. After all, nothing we know about Lucy 
suggests an affinity for art, but statistics and probability 
are useful in poker. And yet, this is the wrong answer. Look at the options again. How do we know the first statement 
is more likely to be true? Because it’s a less specific version 
of the second statement. Saying that Lucy is a portrait artist 
doesn’t make any claims about what else she might or might not do. But even though it’s far easier to imagine
her playing poker than making art based on the background information, the second statement is only true if she 
does both of these things. However counterintuitive it seems 
to imagine Lucy as an artist, the second scenario adds another condition
on top of that, making it less likely. For any possible set of events, the 
likelihood of A occurring will always be greater than the likelihood
of A and B both occurring. If we took a random sample of a million 
people who majored in math, the subset who are portrait artists might 
be relatively small. But it will necessarily be bigger than the subset who are portrait artists 
and play poker. Anyone who belongs to the second group 
will also belong to the first– but not vice versa. The more conditions there are, 
the less likely an event becomes. So why do statements with more conditions
sometimes seem more believable? This is a phenomenon known as 
the conjunction fallacy. When we’re asked to make quick decisions, 
we tend to look for shortcuts. In this case, we look for what seems 
plausible rather than what is statistically 
most probable. On its own, Lucy being an artist doesn’t 
match the expectations formed by the preceding information. The additional detail about 
her playing poker gives us a narrative that resonates 
with our intuitions— it makes it seem more plausible. And we choose the option that seems more
representative of the overall picture, regardless of its actual probability. This effect has been observed 
across multiple studies, including ones with participants 
who understood statistics well– from students betting on 
sequences of dice rolls, to foreign policy experts predicting 
the likelihood of a diplomatic crisis. The conjunction fallacy isn’t just a 
problem in hypothetical situations. Conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction
fallacy to seem credible– the more resonant details are added 
to an outlandish story, the more plausible it begins to seem. But ultimately, the likelihood 
a story is true can never be greater than the probability 
that its least likely component is true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Which of the following does NOT explain why A is always more likely than A and B?
Options: A. B contradicts A, B. A contains fewer conditions, C. A is true in all cases where A and B is true
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the phenomenon discussed in the transcript where adding more conditions to a statement makes it less likely to be true? Options: A. The conjunction fallacy, B. The probability fallacy, C. The narrative bias, D. The confirmation bias Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the transcript, what percentage of participants in similar studies chose the equivalent of the second statement: that Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker? Options: A. 50%, B. 60%, C. 80%, D. 90% Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main reason why the first statement (Lucy is a portrait artist) is more likely to be true than the second statement (Lucy is a portrait artist who also plays poker)? Options: A. Because it's a more specific version of the second statement, B. Because it's a less specific version of the second statement, C. Because it's a more general statement, D. Because it's a more abstract statement Correct Option: B
Question 4: According to the transcript, what happens when we add more conditions to a statement? Options: A. The likelihood of the statement becomes greater, B. The likelihood of the statement remains the same, C. The likelihood of the statement becomes less, D. The likelihood of the statement becomes more uncertain Correct Option: C
Question 5: In what context is the conjunction fallacy most likely to occur? Options: A. When making quick decisions, B. When analyzing complex data, C. When evaluating evidence, D. When solving mathematical problems Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to the transcript, why do conspiracy theories and false news stories often rely on a version of the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Because they want to seem credible, B. Because they want to seem plausible, C. Because they want to seem believable, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the relationship between the likelihood of a statement and the likelihood of its least likely component? Options: A. The likelihood of the statement is always greater than the likelihood of its least likely component, B. The likelihood of the statement is always less than the likelihood of its least likely component, C. The likelihood of the statement is equal to the likelihood of its least likely component, D. The likelihood of the statement can be greater than, less than, or equal to the likelihood of its least likely component Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, why do people tend to fall victim to the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. Because they are unaware of the concept, B. Because they are not familiar with statistics, C. Because they look for what seems plausible rather than what is statistically most probable, D. Because they are not able to think critically Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the relationship between the conjunction fallacy and the narrative bias? Options: A. The conjunction fallacy is a type of narrative bias, B. The narrative bias is a type of conjunction fallacy, C. The conjunction fallacy and narrative bias are unrelated, D. The conjunction fallacy is a result of the narrative bias Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the main takeaway from understanding the conjunction fallacy? Options: A. That we should always choose the option that seems most plausible, B. That we should always choose the option that is statistically most probable, C. That we should be aware of the conjunction fallacy and avoid falling victim to it, D. That we should always trust our intuition Correct Option: C

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

However, it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ, as the question and options are not identical. But among the provided generated MCQs, Question 3 is the closest match in terms of question intent and content.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
In 1948, Spanish ophthalmologist 
Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner was fed up with glasses. He wanted a solution for blurry 
vision that fixed the eye itself, without relying on external aids. But the surgery he eventually devised 
was not for the faint of heart. Barraquer began by slicing off the front
of a patient’s cornea and dunking it in liquid nitrogen. Using a miniature lathe, he ground the 
frozen cornea into the precise shape necessary to focus
the patient’s vision. Then he thawed the disc, and sewed 
it back on. Barraquer called this procedure 
keratomileusis, from the Greek words for “carving” 
and “cornea.” And though it might sound grisly, 
his technique produced reliable results. So how did Barraquer’s surgery work? Keratomileusis corrects what are called 
refractive errors: imperfections in the way the eye focuses 
incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too
large to easily change shape and shift focus. Glasses and contact lenses bend light 
to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch 
words into a human hair. To safely accomplish these 
ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the 
inside of the cornea. Guided by the refractive error and the 
shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30 
seconds for each eye. Finally, the flap is closed, and its edges reseal themselves 
in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ 
keratomileusis” – but you probably know it as LASIK. Essentially, this technique carves a 
patient’s contact lens prescription onto their cornea. Like any surgical procedure, LASIK comes with certain risks. Some patients experience slightly blurred
vision that can’t be corrected by glasses. But the technique is currently about 
as likely to damage your eyes as wearing daily disposable contact 
lenses for one year. Today, a technique called SMILE enables 
surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: 5. In addition to far-sightedness and short-sightedness, LASIK can also treat which one of the following?
Options: A. Astigmatism, B. Age related decreased reading ability, C. Myopia, D. Hyperopia, E. All of the above
Correct Option: E

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: Who is credited with developing the surgical procedure of keratomileusis? Options: A. Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner, B. A Spanish ophthalmologist, C. A modern eye surgeon, D. A Greek physician Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the primary goal of keratomileusis? Options: A. To correct refractive errors, B. To improve eye sight, C. To cure eye diseases, D. To reduce eye strain Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the main difference between myopia and hyperopia? Options: A. Myopia is caused by a flat cornea, while hyperopia is caused by a steep cornea, B. Myopia is caused by a steep cornea, while hyperopia is caused by a flat cornea, C. Myopia is caused by a curved cornea, while hyperopia is caused by a straight cornea, D. Myopia is caused by a straight cornea, while hyperopia is caused by a curved cornea Correct Option: B
Question 4: How does LASIK surgery work? Options: A. By grinding the cornea into the correct shape, B. By etching words into the cornea, C. By separating a thin layer from the front of the cornea and then sculpting the exposed corneal bed, D. By heating the cornea with a laser Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the name of the technique used to create a plane beneath the corneal surface in LASIK surgery? Options: A. Photoablation, B. Excimer laser, C. Femto-second laser, D. Plasma bubbles Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the main advantage of LASIK surgery over traditional corrective methods? Options: A. It is more invasive, B. It is less invasive, C. It is more expensive, D. It is less effective Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the name of the technique that allows surgeons to adjust one eye to be slightly better at distance vision and the other to be better at close range vision? Options: A. Laser Blended Vision, B. LASIK, C. Keratomileusis, D. Photoablation Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the primary benefit of advances in laser technology for vision correction surgery? Options: A. It is more invasive, B. It is less effective, C. It is more accessible, D. It is more expensive Correct Option: C
Question 9: What is the name of the surgical procedure developed by Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner that involves carving the cornea into the correct shape? Options: A. Keratomileusis, B. LASIK, C. Photoablation, D. Excimer laser Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the ultimate goal of Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner's vision for vision correction surgery? Options: A. To make it more invasive, B. To make it less effective, C. To make it more accessible and to eventually eliminate the need for glasses, D. To make it more expensive Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I have identified the most similar generated MCQ as:

**Question 2: What is the primary goal of keratomileusis?** is not the most similar, however, 
**Question 3: What is the main difference between myopia and hyperopia?** is related but it does not include all the three conditions mentioned in the ground truth MCQ.

However, there isn't a direct match to the ground truth MCQ among the generated MCQs. But if we were to choose one that is somewhat related to the ground truth MCQ:

**Question 9: What is the name of the surgical procedure developed by Jose Ignacio Barraquer Moner that involves carving the cornea into the correct shape?** is not the most similar but among the given options, question 2 is the one that includes the concept of refractive errors which myopia, hyperopia and astigmatism are types of.

However, since question 2 does not include the options myopia, hyperopia and astigmatism and question 3 only includes myopia and hyperopia but not astigmatism, none of the questions are a perfect match.

But if we really had to choose one, I would say **Question 2** is the closest in terms of the concept of refractive errors which is what myopia, hyperopia and astigmatism are.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 2

incoming light. Ideally, the cornea and lens work 
together to focus light on the surface of the retina, but several kinds of refractive errors 
can impair this delicate system. In people with myopia, 
or short-sightedness, a steep cornea focuses light just short 
of the retina. Those with hyperopia, or far-sightedness, 
have the opposite problem: light is focused too far 
beyond the retina. And in people with astigmatism, 
the cornea has two different curvatures which focus light at two distances and 
produce blurry vision. Even those with perfect vision will 
eventually suffer from presbyopia, or “aging eyes.” As the proteins in the lens age, they 
slowly increase its size. By an adult’s mid-40’s, the lens is too

to compensate for these refractive errors. But, as Barraquer’s procedure shows, we can also alter the shape 
of the cornea itself; moving the focal point backwards, 
forwards, or pulling a divided image together. And thankfully, modern eye surgeons can 
sculpt the cornea with far less invasive tools. In corrective laser eye surgery, surgeons 
rely on excimer lasers. These tools are accurate enough to etch

ultra-fine incisions, they use a technique called photoablation. This allows the laser to essentially 
evaporate organic tissue without overheating 
surrounding eye tissue. So how does laser eye surgery 
actually work? The first step is to separate a thin layer
from the front of the cornea. This can be done with either a flat, 
wide blade, or a femto-second laser that produces millions of tiny plasma 
bubbles to create a plane beneath 
the corneal surface. Surgeons then lift the flap to expose the

shape of the cornea, the excimer laser robotically sculpts the
exposed corneal bed into the correct shape. This process usually takes less than 30

in just a few hours. Because the lasering is done on 
the eyeball itself, it’s described as “in situ,” or “on site.” Its complete name is “laser in-situ

surgeons to sculpt the cornea through even smaller incisions – further reducing recovery time. And lasers aren’t just correcting the 
three types of refractive errors – this technology can also 
restore aging eyes. In a technique called Laser 
Blended Vision, surgeons adjust one eye to be slightly 
better at distance vision and the other to be better 
at close range vision. The difference between the two eyes is 
small enough that most patients can merge their vision, allowing both eyes to work 
together at all distances. Advances in laser technology continue 
to make vision correction surgery more effective and accessible. One day soon, Barraquer’s vision of a 
world without glasses may finally come true.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In Myopia, the eye is focused at ________, is the medical term used for define which one of the following?
